sentence.text: to be completely fair, the only redeeming factor was the food, which was above average, but couldn't make up for all the other deficiencies of teodora.
all the money went into the interior decoration, none of it went to the chefs.
faan's got a great concept but a little rough on the delivery.
the price is reasonable although the service is poor.
pricey, but worth a try, at least once.
unfortunately, the food is outstanding, but everything else about this restaurant is the pits.
they are often crowded on the weekends but they are efficient and accurate with their service.
it may be a bit packed on weekends, but the vibe is good and it is the best french food you will find in the area.
overall a oh ya even though there is waiting it is deff worth it
good selection of wines ranging from affordable to high end.
this place is really trendi but they have forgotten about the most important part of a restaurant, the food.
service could be improved but overall this is a place that understands the importance of little things (the heavy, black, antique-seeming teapot, for one) in the restaurant experience.
eating in, the atmosphere saves it, but at your desk, it's a very disappointing experience.
granted the space is smaller than most, it is the best service you will find in even the largest of restaurants.
the environment is romantic, but the food is horrible, the service is pathetic, and gabriella lies about everything she could.
if you're craving for haru's great food, especially the house roll, but can't stand the wait building outside, head across the street to their sake bar!
would have rather tried terrace in the sky or water club for that price
they might be all business at the counter when you give your order, but their food says i love you.
lived in shanghai most of my life and thought the food was comparable to the flagship green bo restaurant there.
the menu looked good, except for offering the chilean sea bass, but the server does not offer up the specials that were written on the board outside.

since it literally is a complete hole in the wall, it's a bit intimidating at first, but you get over that very quickly as soon as the friendly staff welcomes you - don't hesitate to ask for help with what to get.
it costs $2 extra to turn a regular roll into an inside-out roll, but the roll more than triples in size, and that's not just from the rice.
the food is great, service is ok.
the rest of the dim sum, though pricey by chinatown standards, is worth it.
the lobster sandwich is $24 and although it was good it was not nearly enough to warrant that price.

the italian food has flavor (that can be sort of surprising on the ues), and the service turns from a nightmare to attentive,they sort of remind me of the ny yankees of the late 90's, no matter how bad it look, you knew that there was a rally just around the corner.
the atmosphere is noisy and the waiters are literally walking around doing things as fast as they can.
the ambience was nice, but service wasn't so great.
the location and ambience is ok but the food is what makes up for it.
while we thoroughly enjoyed the food, it was annoying to scream across the table for conversation.

while the $20 entree range is not overly expensive, in new york city, there is definitely better food in that range, and so sapphire, despite it's lovely atmosphere, will most likely not be a restaurant to which i will return.
prices are higher to dine in and their chicken tikka marsala is quite good.
the restaurant is rather small but we were lucky to get a table quickly.
i was a little leary about mary's at first - it's small, crowded and you usually have to wait on line - but i'm glad i finally tried it.
the restaurant itself is not large, but seems to have several round tables to accommodate large groups hoping to save a buck to eat authentic taiwanese.
we were fans of the half-price saturday night option until some inedible squid during a recent visit.
the food is reliable and the price is moderate.
while the ambiance and atmosphere were great, the food and service could have been a lot better.
the food is usually good but it certainly isn't a relaxing place to go.
still, any quibbles about the bill were off-set by the pour-your-own measures of liqueurs which were courtesy of the house.
even though its good seafood, the prices are too high.
it won't break the bank but i also wouldn't come back for the food.
my first time there i happened not to like the crab croquette apt that i ordered and they were happy to change it for me without making no big deal.
however, in the summer of 2003, it seems the management has changed and the great big door has been replaced for a glass front ridding itself of the dark romantic getup.
outstanding bagels, but you get what you pay for.
the svc can be a bit rude at times, esp if you have big group, but overall the restaurant is a must!
while the place is not a hotspot hangout, the drinks are unique and pack a lot of bang for the buck.
it's a shame that a nice, convenient place like the pink pony can be so ruined by lousy service.
while the food was excellent, it wasn't cheap (though not extremely expensive either).
as much as i like the food there, i can't bring myself to go back.

nha trang, while being notorious for utter lack of comfort and decor, horribly slow wait staff and horribly quick meals, is one of the best vietnamese restaurants i've ever been to. the pho is delicious and comes with very fresh vegetables.

on the other hand, if you are not fooled easily, you will find hundreds of restaurants that will give you service and ambiance that is on par with alain ducasse, and food that will outshine in presentation, taste, choice, quality and quantity.
if i could rate the people this place would be off the charts - unfortunately - the pizza, sorry - not the best in nyc.
the portions are now very small, the sauces are overly-ambitious usually inedible while the service is still good, the restaurant, due to its popularity, seems frantic.
the service is a little scatty at times but all is forgiven when the food arrives.
the atmosphere isn't the greatest , but i suppose that's how they keep the prices down .
i would go again if i didn't have to pay.
delicious food at a great price but do not go here on a cold day and sit by the front door.
overall, i'm still impressed that the place even exists and the prices are quite decent but then again, its chinatown.
decent thai food in cute - though a bit dank - little nolita hangout, but service terrible.
sushi wasn't anything spectacular for the price.
so, for good food i'd recommend it, but not for a fun night out.
while the food was good (certainly no il mulino) the service was horrendous.
the food was very expensive (we spent $160 for lunch for two) but extremely tasty.
we were a group of 8 and well served.
an excellent alternative to fast food joints and ordering in but, the food was slightly disappointing.
sometimes i get good food and ok service.
it's a place for people who pay a lot for mediocre food, noise and a chance to be with their fellow bridge and tunnel folks.
a little overpriced but worth it once you take a bite.
we actually gave 10% tip (which we have never done despite mediocre food and service), because we felt totally ripped off.
while we enjoyed the food, we were highly disappointed by the poor service (waiter was not quite competent and slow service) and lack of remorse.
the restaurant is a bit noisy but that is something that can be overlooked once you sit down and enjoy a great meal
i have eaten at saul, many times, the food is always consistently, outrageously good.
although the tables may be closely situated, the candle light, food quality and service overcompensate.
this little place definitely exceeded my expectations and you sure get a lot of food for your money.
tasty but expensive.
i am relatively new to the area and tried pick a bagel on 2nd and was disappointed with the service and i thought the food was overrated and on the pricey side.
the food is expensive, but worth every bite.
sometimes i get bad food and bad service, sometimes i get good good and bad service.
i was in love with pongsri on 48th, but compared to suan it is slow in service and overpriced.
maybe i say so because it looked promising for people who like artery-clogging jewish deli food, but turns out to be poorly run and awful.
wait staff is blatantly unappreciative of your business but its the best pie on the uws!
having discovered ping's on the internet, we entered with qualms but were instantly put to ease by the fish tanks that greet you as u walk in.
overall the restaurant is more expensive than our other sushi favorites, but everything was delicious.
the menu is prix fixe, so be prepared to spend at least $60 per person, but it is well worth it superb food.
when we left at 8:00 pm, it was packed and noisy.
aside from the rushed service, we were very impressed with the food and the drinks.
while the new restaurant still features much of the same classical furniture that made tiffin so attractive, the menu has been overhauled.
the people with carts of food don't understand you because they don't speak english, their job is to give you the delicious food you point at.
not the greatest sushi place, but excellent for a $19.95 all you can eat.
the food was mediocre at best but it was the horrible service that made me vow never to go back.
other than being a little crowded and a bit overpriced, the atmosphere is filled with energy (and the beautiful people of course) and the food was surprising good!
the first time i went, and was completely taken by the live jazz band and atmosphere, i ordered the lobster cobb salad.
this place has good potential, but needs a significant amount of work before we can justify spending that much money on indian food you can get everywhere else.
if you've ever been along the river in weehawken you have an idea of the top of view the chart house has to offer.
total hipster-wannabe attitude in an otherwise sweet spot.
the food was just ok, i would never go back.
my fiance took me to scopa last week for my birthday and i couldn't believe the food.
a bit breezy up there on the mezzanine from the wind coming from the tracks.
the food itself was just ok - nothing spectacular - but the service was awful.
try the spicy shrimp appetizer (again, not the greatest value in the world but worth the price) and the lamb vindaloo is great.
however, go for the ambience, and consider the food just a companion for a trip across the world!
food was good not great not worth the wait or another visit
also, if you don't want to sit at a certain table, you don't have to!
a little pricey but it really hits the spot on a sunday morning!
the staff isn't the friendliest or most competent, and i am stickler for service, but everything else about this place makes up for it.
service is friendly, prices are good - delivery time was a little slow, but for the way this pizza tastes, i'm willing to overlook it.
the food can get pricey but the prixe fixe tasting menu is the greatest food for a good price and they cater the food to any food allergies or food you don't like.
the place is small and cramped but the food is fantastic.
a little crowded but they move that line really fast!
the food there is so good that even to order out the wait is incredible.
they offer the same menu but have creative drinks that are loaded with alcohol and cheeky names -- but they do cost you.
thalia is a beautiful restaurant with beautiful people serving you, but the food doesn't quite match up.
the service is friendly, if not the most prompt in the world, the food is great, and the prices, while not cheap, won't put your wallet out of commission.
i do suggest to ask to be seated upstairs if you are looking to be a little cozy.
i would recommend roxy's for that, but not for their food.
the puke green walls leave a lot to be desired, but the food is very good.
no food snobs allowed, this place is for people who appreciate good food.
while sapphire is certainly not lacking in ambiance, and probably has the best decor of any indian restaurant i have been to in new york city, the food was not what i had hoped for.
i have been a longtime fan of holy basil in the east village, and while i do believe their food has slightly slipped in quality, i have been hesitant to be disloyal.
you don't go to mizu for excellent service, you go for the large amounts of food, the amiable atmosphere, and the hole-in-the-wall feeling of the place.
the food here is rather good, but only if you like to wait for it.
this is a cute place and could be good but they need to get their act together.
we actually left hungry and went across the street to wo hop at 15 mott street for some good chinese food.
bottom line: b+ for the food, f for the service.
the food is good, but very expensive for the casualness of it.
i went here with a friend on a whim, we went someplace else first and couldn't get a table.
20 minutes for our reservation but it gave us time to have a few cocktails and enjoy our surroundings and each other.
in any event, even though its a bit on the pricey side, we still love this restaurant and will definitely go back.
our waiter was fine, the place looks nice in that not-trying-too-hard way, but at those prices, a little more should be expected of your food.
average to good thai food, but terrible delivery.
the space is nice but when we order our drink we were in for a surprise.
this is, by far, my favorite restaurant in nyc and i only wish it were more affordable so i could go more often!
we all had the tasting menu and unlike some of the other reviews, i felt there was more than enough food.
- for dessert we split chocolate cake and vanilla gelato (with espresso), which were tasty, but i thought a bit overpriced.
we ran a little late for the reservation but it wasn't a problem to get our table immediately.
we arrived on time for our reservation and seated promptly.
you will pay a lot for the decore, but the food is no better or worse than a lot of other chinese and asian fusion places in ny.
while this is a pretty place in that overly cute french way, the food was insultingly horrible.
great wine list (italian), good food, service was initially fine.
unlike other places in nyc where the sandwiches you want only come as a triple-decker, here you can get what you want in a reasonably sized portion (and price).
staffs are not that friendly, but the taste covers all.
the tables are crammed way too close, the menu is typical of any italian restaurant, and the wine list is simply overpriced.
the sushi is average and the prices are anything but.
while the room is not particularly comfortable, once you're seated you'll forget about everything except what's on your plate.
i've lived in nyc all my life and had never before seen so many waterbugs in one place (except in a really bad dream).
the ambiance is minimal the food is not phenomenal, but some dishes are quite good, such as the eggplant parmesan, veal in carozza chicken saltimbocca.
edible but really a ripoff at those prices given whats in the area.
the staff has been nice, but they seemed really stressed and the unisex bathroom needs to be cleaned more often.
do not try unless you're just going there to hang out like the rest of the hipsters who apparently have no sense of taste.
the place is small and intimate and you may feel a little crowded, but the service is excellent and it's great for friends out, a romantic date, or a special occasion.

the sushi has been from average to below average, the wait service has always been sub-par the atmosphere goes from nice to really irritating (if you sit in the area beyond the kitchen, the acoustics are horrid, everything echoes is extremely loud).
spreads and toppings are great - though a bit pricey.
the cafe itself was really nice with comfortable outdoor chairs and tables, but the service could have been better.
good food at the restaurant (a bit expensive, but great if you want to impress your date).
from the moment we walked in they were more than accommodating even though the place was packed.
the drinks are a saving grace, but service staff, please, get over yourselves.
while most people can attest to spending over $50 on drinks in new york bars and hardly feeling a thing, the drinks here are plentiful and unique.
while this can hardly be called a restaurant, it is possibly the best deal in manhattan: $4 for a plate heaped with rice and 2-3 entrees.
they did give a 15% discount at the end, wasn't enough, as they knew the service was horrible.
such nice people working here - but i have to review the food.
the service was mediocre, and the lack of air conditioning made for a less than comfortable meal.
however, if you want great food at a great price and don't mind the decor, you can't beat this place.
sake collection was excellent (try nanbu bijin), but pricey.
rude service, medicore food...there are tons of restaurants in ny...stay away from this one
although the tables may be closely situated, the candle-light, food-quality and service overcompensate.
this place is pricey, and yes, the food is worth it; but the service makes you feel like you should be paying a quater of the price.
downtown dinner 2002 - prixe fix: appetizers were ok, waiter gave me poor suggestion..try the potato stuff kanish best one.
still, any quibbles about the bill were off-set by the pour-your-own measures of liquers which were courtesy of the house...
food was just average...if they lowered the prices just a bit, it would be a bigger draw.
rude service, mediocre food...there are tons of restaurants in ny...stay away from this one
this place is really trendy but they have forgotten about the most important part of a restaurant, the food.
still, any quibbles about the bill were off-set by the pour-your-own measures of liqueurs which were courtesy of the house...
excellent food, although the interior could use some help.
the place is a bit hidden away, but once you get there, it's all worth it.
the space is limited so be prepared to wait up to 45 minutes - 1 hour, but be richly rewarded when you savor the delicious indo-chinese food.
overpriced japanese food with mediocre service
the food was excellent as well as service, however, i left the four seasons very disappointed.
decor needs to be upgraded but the food is amazing!
the high prices you're going to pay is for the view not for the food.
the wine list was extensive - though the staff did not seem knowledgeable about wine pairings.
the dessert (we had a pear torte) was good - but, once again, the staff was unable to provide appropriate drink suggestions.
not what i would expect for the price and prestige of this location.
all in all, i would return - as it was a beautiful restaurant - but i hope the staff pays more attention to the little details in the future.
over all the looks of the place exceeds the actual meals.
so what you really end up paying for is the restaurant not the food.
food took some time to prepare, all worth waiting for.
for a restaurant with such a good reputation and that is usually so packed, there was no reason for such a lack of intelligent customer service.
despite the confusing mirrors this will likely be my go-to for modern japanese food for the foreseeable future.
not a very fancy place but very good chinese style indian food.
for me dishes a little oily, but overall dining experience good.
even though the place is not beautiful, the food speaks for itself.
what you are paying for is the environment and the name.
yes, the place is classy and beautiful, but they most certainly target the uber whealthy not the common joe that wants to go all out every once in a while.
the appetizers we ordered were served quickly - an order of fried oysters and clams were delicious but a tiny portion (maybe 3 of each).

i have it a 4 instead of 5 because of the price (just chicken tikka masala - no bread of rice - is $25), which i would expect at a upscale indian restaurant but this place doesn't have an upscale feel.
but if you're prepared to spend some $ and remember to ask if something they offer is complimentary, then this is the place to go for indian food
not only is it an adventure getting to this somewhat hidden spot, once you enter the unmarked wooden doors, the zen and intimate dcor will make you feel like youre no longer in the city.
price is high but the food is good, so i would come back again.
the food was great and tasty, but the sitting space was too small, i don't like being cramp in a corner.
the food we ordered was excellent, although i wouldn't say the margaritas were anything to write home about.
a different server enhanced the fun, dumping our entrees in front of us halfway through our appetizer (which was delicious).
overall the food quality was pretty good, though i hear the salmon is much better when it hasn't sat cooling in front of the guest.
the place has a nice fit-out, some attractive furnishings and, from what i could tell, a reasonable wine list (i was given the food menu when i asked for the carte des vins)
everything was going good until we got our meals.
the manager came to the table and said we can do what we want, so we paid for what we did enjoy, the drinks and appetizers, and walked out.
the decor however seems to be the distraction so you won't notice that you just payed 300 bucks for some cold eggplant that took 2 frickin hours to come!!!!
though it's been crowded most times i've gone here, bark always delivers on their food.
fabulous food - if the front of house staff don't put you off

each time we've been, the front of house staff (not the waiters - they're fantastic - but the people who greet and seat you) has been so hideous to us that were it not for the exceptional fish dishes i would never return.
the food and service were fine, however the maitre-d was incredibly unwelcoming and arrogant.
at first glance this place seems a bit pricey for a hot dog joint, but at bark you don't just get your average hot dog.
